I do both with investigations and such, bring along analog and digital
recorders (and being a musician I still work with both technologies as
well).  There's certain tonal and depth qualities that get sampled out
in digital as well as different types of artifacting that digital
produces, just as there's certain clarities not capable in analog with
out a lot of extra work besides the ease of use of the medium.


Marty

> Hi Judy. I think if that type of research interests you and you can
afford the $160 (and 
> anything else you might need to go along with it for EVP purposes),
why not? For myself, I 
> just find it to be too time consuming and frustrating to go through
so much recorded 
> material for so little in return, content wise, when we already have
the ability (albeit in it's 
> infancy) to engage in real-time, or nearly real-time, two-way
conversations.
> 
> Yes, Sarah got amazing results and bless her pioneering spirit which
helped bring us to 
> where we are today. I'm not sure how much of her success was her
equipment and how 
> much was her energy (I think we are all a component in our
sessions). In regard to 
> traditional EVP work, given how good many of today's inexpensive
digital recorders are, 
> that is the route I've gone for situations where sweep isn't an
option. I've gotten good EVP 
> with my Panasonic RR-US360, the Sony B26, and a handful of others. I
know some are 
> still successfully using cassettes. 
> 
> I guess it all boils down to a matter of preference and the type of
EVP research that most 
> interests you. As my dear hubby says, "Whatever floats your boat!" ;-)
> 
> If you do decide to try Sarah's method, let us know how you do.
> 
> Margaret
